sect1.title: Religion
sect1.para: The gods of Harn are real, and the powers they grant to their priests are just as real. Described here are rules for playing priests in Harn using Yags. For a complete description of the gods and their beliefs, see the HarnMaster Religion supplement.

sect3.title: Levels of Knowledge
sect3.para: There are three levels of knowledge which define what cult invocations are taught to a trainee priest. Invocations of level I are taught to all initiates by their mentor. Village priests will have most, if not all, level I cult invocations, of some level. In game terms, a priest character can begin with knowledge of any level I invocation up to the normal limit of knowledge.

Level II invocations are those which are revealed only to those who have proven themselves to those above them. Often, village priests will have no knowledge of these, but wandering priests may perform the services needed from time to time, occasionally stopping to teach the secrets to those in great need who have shown diligence in the faith.
Knowledge of the Level III invocations is restricted to the highest levels of the priestly orders, and only those who have risen in the ranks will be taught them.

sect2.title: Using Cult Invocations
sect2.para: Cult invocations may be taught to anyone, though only those favoured by the god may find any use from that knowledge. A cult invocation is a mixture of prayer, ceremony and sacrifice as well as actual skill.

The invocation skill is always rolled against charisma. If the invocation affects another person directly (e.g. It does not take some physical form), then the target gets a will roll to resist. Their will is opposed against the priest's will, with the priest getting a bonus of one fifth of their invocation roll.

sect3.title: Sacrifice
sect3.para: One of the demands of the skill is that a suitable sacrifice is made to the god during the prayer ceremony. The nature of the sacrifice depends on the god, and the ritual that is being used. It can range from a share of the crops, the loss of a valuable item, or the sacrifice of an animal, or even a person.

sect4.title: Material Cost
sect4.para: The material cost the sacrifice is given with the invocation description, and is rated from low, to very high. This is relative to the earnings of the person who is benefitting from the invocation.

If the cost is noted as immediate, then the sacrifice must be paid before, or as, the invocation is made. Otherwise, it is possible to delay the sacrifice until afterwards. How long afterwards is up to the priest, though as soon as possible is generally a good idea to avoid invoking the displeasure of their deity.
As a general guide, the following costs of the material sacrificed can be used.
Low: A token amount, generally amounting to half a day's earnings.

sect4.title: Spiritual Cost
sect4.para: Some invocations have a spiritual cost as well. This cost is in luck points, which must be paid immediately. This is shown as /x after the material cost, where x is the number of luck points.

This loss of luck is normally temporary, though if the invocation was used in a way the god is not happy with, it will be permanent. Generally, use of an invocation in a way that goes directly against the god's wishes will be forbidden, whilst unnecessary use of their power will result in luck being lost.

sect3.title: Effects of an Invocation
sect3.para: Invocations are not subtle. If a god is going to be bothered to interfere amongst mortals, then they want to advertise the fact. An invocation must clearly name the deity. A successful invocation will produce obvious special effects. A protected person might glow, a healing invocation might produce glowing lights around the person as they are healed. A curse will strike a person down with flames, darkness or a ray of light, depending on the preference of the deity.
The effects of Naveh tend to involve darkness, a shimmer around the object affected or similar illusory effects.
Agrik and Larani tend to be bright, and very obvious. Sarajin's invocations will tend to summon an icy wind, or a layer of frost.

sect3.title: Resisting Invocations
sect3.para: It is possible to resist the effects of an invocation, though only if the invocation affects a target directly. An invocation that causes a pillar of fire to strike a target does not allow resistance (other than soak). An invocation which causes disease in a target does.

The resistance is the will of the target against the will of the priest, with the priest getting a bonus equal to their invocation skill. Both priest and target also each gain a bonus equal to their current luck.
A resistance roll which fails by 10 or more causes the invocation to be a critical success, which may have an additional effect, depending on the invocation.

sect2.title: Cult Skills
sect2.para: Cult skills are further secrets of a religion, though unlike rituals they are totally mundane, but simply not well known. Most are closely guarded secrets, though some are simply restricted to a particular religion because no one else has a need for them.

Learning cult skills is restricted, in that anyone with less than level four in the skill can only improve by having another teach them. Once level four has been reached, improvement can be through self study and experience as for other skills.

sect2.title: Aura
sect2.para: All living things have an aura, which can sometimes be determined through religious rituals. The aura of a person or creature gives an insight into their nature, personality and religious beliefs.
Any religious ritual which allows a priest to divine the aura of a person uses the following guide for use of their ritual skill.

row.entry: The bloodline or basic nature of the target is known. Whether someone is Human, Sindarin, Faerie or an elemental or demonoic spirit is known.
Elemental and divine affinities, if any. Shek-Pvar who are attuned to an element will have an aura tainted by that element. Priests of a god are also bound to their god, and this affects their aura.
The physical and mental well being of the target is known. Roughly how exhausted, injured and hungry the target is can be determined, as well as their primary emotions.
Knowledge of a person's morals, in regard to whether they are good or evil is obtained.
If the target has any leanings towards Law or Chaos, then this can be determined.
The religion of the target, even if they are not a priest. Also given, is a general guide to how strongly they follow the ideals of their faith.

sect2.title: Divine Intervention
sect2.para: Invocations are not the only way in which a god may aid one of their followers. They are heavy on ritual and ceremony, and can only be used by those who are part of the mainstream church (since they will not be taught to anyone else).

Any follower of a god however may call for divine intervention. Divine aid takes a round to be called for, though the character may perform other actions whilst doing so. However, the call for divine intervention must be made vocally, in a loud, clear voice. The name of the god must be invoked, and the nature of the request must be stated.

Assuming that the request does not go against the morals of the god, then there is a chance that the god will intervene on behalf of their follower. The character spends a number of points of luck, and rolls for intervention as follows.
luck spent 5
The luck spent is always lost permanently, regardless of the outcome. The target number that must be obtained depends on how worthy the request is.

sect2.title: Priest Characters
sect2.para: The majority of priests attain priesthood after spending many years training in a religious institution. There, they are taught the tenants of their faith, as well as the basic invocations and cult skills they are expected to learn.

Player character priests will normally be at least 21 years old. Characters younger than this will rarely have had time to learn all the necessary skills, and will be considered an acolyte, rather than a full priest.
Priests of all religions will have the following common invocations:
Blessing 2
They will also have the following skills: Religion (their own) 4 Scribe (their own) 4
These do need to be paid for.

sect1.title: Common Invocations
sect1.para: Common invocations are available to, and taught by, priests of all religions. However, they are different in the details, so the invocation skill for Blessing (Morgath) is very different to that for Blessing (Larani).

Many of the common invocations are based off the same invocation skill. There are three meta-invocations - Blessing, Channel and Divination. All priests start with at least knowledge of Blessing. This provides knowledge of the basic ceremonies the priest has to be able to perform, in order to contact their god, perform baptism's, marriage and funeral rites.
Invocations which make use of these meta-invocations will name them in parenthesis after the invocation title.

sect1.title: Agrik
sect1.para: Lord of the Four Horsemen
The fiery, evil god of war, favoured by those who enjoy cruelty and destruction. Agrik is worshiped by dozens of squabbling clerical sects and fighting orders.

sect4.title: Torture
sect4.para: Knowledge of how to torture a person, without actually killing them. This is rolled opposed against the victim's will to try and break them.

sect4.title: Berserk
sect4.para: This skill enables the priest to enter a berserk rage.

sect1.title: Halea
sect1.para: Enslaver of Hearts and Loins
The goddess of wealth and pleasure. She demands unswerving devotion and her adherents. Only women can enter her clergy.

sect3.title: Erotic arts
sect3.para: The skill of giving pleasure to someone. Also includes various forms of exotic dancing and knowledge of how to dress and present oneself in order to create desire in others, as well as simply being very, very good in bed.

sect1.title: Ilvir
sect1.para: Prince of the Fatherless Multitude
The creator of the Ivashu. His followers are individualists, creative, and mystical. Dozens of sects worship Ilvir, although his adherents are few and mostly found in Orbaal.

sect1.title: Larani
sect1.para: Lady of Paladins
The Lady of Paladins is the goddess of chivalry and battle, favoured by the feudal nobility. Those who follow her are expected to display courage, compassion and honour.

Despite being a goddess of War, Larani despises violence, and believes that it should only be used as a last resort. Her followers vary greatly in how closely they follow this particular ideal, the militant orders of her church can be especially lax at times at avoiding violent confrontation.
There are two clerical orders - The Spear of Shattered Sorrow and the Order of Hyvrik. Both have martial and non-martial members, though all (in theory) prefer non-violent solutions to disputes.
The sponsored fighting orders are not taught priestly invocations, unless they have proven themselves worthy over a long period of time.

sect2.title: Common skills
sect2.para: Law; weapon and shield; ride; lance; guile; battle.

sect1.title: Morgath
sect1.para: Tormentor of the Unlamented Dead
Morgath is the master of chaos, evil and the undead, who despises all things fair and noble. His church is dour and ruthless, and infamous for its human sacrifice.

The most feared aspect of priests of Morgath is their ability to create, and control, undead. There are two types of undead - the Amorvrin (willing) and the Gulmorvrin (unwilling). The latter are far more common.

sect2.title: Encounters with the Shadow
sect2.para: Amorvrin may have a shadow extending beyond their bodies. Entering this, or touching a morvrus, is generally not a good idea. It is an extension of Bukrai # the power of Morgath.

Contact with the Shadow causes an immediate mental attack on the living soul. The morvrus attacks with its will, as per a damage roll which is soaked with the living soul's own will. Damage is suffered in fatigue levels. Each round of contact causes another will attack.
Note that for a gulmorvrin, touch is enough to initiate this will attack, even if the attack does not get through armour.
If the living creature falls unconscious from fatigue, then they are possessed by the Shadow. The soul is offered two choices - accept it, and become an amorvrus, or refuse it and become gulmorvrus.
In any event, the living creature immediately becomes undead. Their body levels are effectively doubled, and if they are gulmorvrin, they come under the control of the Shadow which possessed them.

The Shadow extends out one metre for each point of will an amorvrin has. If multiple Shadows are overlapping, only one Shadow attack is made, but at increased strength. Use the highest will # 4, plus 1 for each point of will overlapping.

sect1.title: Naveh
sect1.para: Lord of the Pitch Shadow
A god of darkness, best known as the bringer of nightmares, and worshiped by thieves and assassins. His fanatical clerics will commit suicide to prove their faith.

sect1.title: Peoni
sect1.para: Bringer of Life Renewed
The gentle goddess of agriculture and healing, worshiped by most rural folk. Peoni's clergy are divided into celibate male and female orders; both maintain hospitals. Temples are always near poverty.

sect1.title: Sarajin
sect1.para: King of the Icy Wind
The god of battlelust, who demands honour and bravery from his adherents, mostly Ivinians. His sport is war and he sometimes joins human battles.

sect1.title: Save-K'nor
sect1.para: Lord of Puzzles
The god of knowledge and seeker of enlightenment, the Sage of Heaven. His adherents believe that a stable and ordered society precludes evil behaviour.

sect1.title: Siem
sect1.para: Master of the Lord of Dreams
The benign god of mystery, magic and dreams. He is the special deity of elves and dwarves. Siem's worshipers favour a personal approach to the deity.
